Don't know if this has been mentioned or not, but there are numerous cars released in the last few years that have "laminated" door glass in the front doors. You have to look at the little black stamp/logo usually in the bottom rear corner of the door glass and if it says "laminated AS2", not even the firemen can get through them. I've been in insurance for 10+ years and have seen this trend emerging. The only thing I can find is the mfg's are saying it's to "better keep the passengers inside the vehicle". However, a vehicle ran into water, you will not save the passengers. You can do your research. Firemen/rescue have had to outfit their rescue gear with special equipment to rip through these laminated door glasses. You can't get through them with a baseball bat. Do some research on that!! You can just search for "laminated door glass" and you will find it.

I pray no one ever carries one of those glass breaking hammers, runs into water, only to find they can't get through the door glass b/c some engineer thought it better to laminate them.

Technically, All cars with headrests have a built-in window breaking tool. It is the metal robs the headrest is mounted on. The reason they allow the headrest to come out of the sockets on the seat is that they are made to be able to be used as window breaking points when striking them against a side window.  Just in case you didn't know. If Destin's hammer had been less flat, it would have broken the side window easily. Focused force is what is needed.  Hence the headrest pointed ends on the mounting rods.

You are not quit right on why car glass is the way it is.  The windshield has a sheet of plastic between 2 sheets of glass.  When you break it the plastic holds the glass to the plastic and doesn't allow the glass to shatter into the passenger compartment thus allowing the occupants to not be cut by broken glass.  If you try to break through a windshield you must break the plastic so it's much harder to break through.  That is why you don't break through the windshield to enter a car.  You break any of the other windows to enter.  The windshield is part of the structural integrity of the roof and a-post of the vehicle to prevent collapse of the roof in a rollover.  A pointed hammer is best suited break tempered window glass.  The other windows are tempered to shatter into little pieces so you don't don't get cut to pieces by big pieces of razor sharp glass.

I really like this video, BUT i really wish you would have said to get a window breaker OR carry something sharp and hard in the car so that you can break the glass easily. a window breaker can be the difference between getting out and not getting out in the wrong situation. so here is what I wish you would have included in the video:

Tempered glass breaks VERY easily from a pin point impact, BUT it is VERY strong against a blunt force impact. So the easiest way to break the glass in a car window is with either a nail and hammer or something else sharp and strong. I personally carry a window breaker that is spring loaded and i was hoping to see one in this video, or at least the non spring loaded equivalent, at the very minimum a nail instead of the hammer head. The problem that this video doesn't consider is the edges of the window will be hidden behind parts of the car door, so you physically can not hit the edges if the window is closed.

I really like this video, but i really wish you had included pin point impact vs blunt impact on tempered glass. This is also why the glass didn't break on the drop test, the surface of the driveway is too blunt of an impact to create that pin point tension break; its not until you use the wrench to simulate a smaller impact that it breaks. That drop test I honestly thought would segway into pin point impacts.

You pretty much got wrong the tempered glass, the "from outside to inside" hardening does not mean the edges are harder, but the surfaces, the difference does not apply in XY plane, but in Z axis (except for very edges of the plate, since those cool from sides too - but thats fraction of inch). Theyre easier to break near the borders, because there is less support from surrounding material, but the tension between the surfaces and the core is uniform regardless where on the panel you measure it.

Nowhere did you instruct or explain "how to escape from a car window". This video is useless for someone trapped inside their car unless they happen to be holding a hammer at the moment their car plummets into water, and they are not injured to the point where they can't swing it with accuracy to hit the edge. If it was elsewhere in the car besides their hand, such as the trunk, then there's a high chance it's now inaccessible, and if it was sitting in the center console then it's buried somewhere in the back (if they're lucky) or they just got a hammer to the face.

The video is however useful to anyone wanting to learn about tempered glass, yet nothing in the title indicates that.

On the annealed glass. Not all annealed glass is laminated. Car windshields are but home windows are not. The windows on the animal exhibits at the zoo are laminated with several sheets of both glass and plastic. The intent behind the laminated glass is to keep all the broken pieces together so they don't injure someone.

Oh the things you learn after manufacturing commercial grade windows for only 3 years.

Older vehicles, I had a 63 Ford truck, will have safety glass in the side windows. I know because there was a long crack in one of them that only went halfway through it. As you know, you cannot merely crack safety glass.

Also many windows are cut to size out of annealed glass and then tempered. I had a window roughly 6 feet by 15 feet in size that was probably hit by a rock traveling just right from a nearby road. I got a call at 4:00 AM from the police. I probably got there within a half an hour and that large pane was still crackling. The same window had broken once before and that was the original annealed glass. The huge shards looked like they could have decapitated someone. The glass company professionals handled it with special gloves. The second time it broke I cleaned it up with a broom much as Justin did at the end of this video.

Though I feel compelled to note just one thing; this is the first SED that I have seen where I might know more about what is going on in the video than even Destin. Solely because I have worked with glass for 15 years.

A few things that might be worth mentioning: both varieties of glass that he tested (because that is what auto makes typically use) are soda-lime glass. That means that in the manufacturing process they start with a typical silica base, and add primarily sodium carbonate, lime, typically small amounts of aluminum and a few other things, melt it, and drag the molten glass out on long conveyors. Interestingly, for annealed glass, the furnace is constantly producing glass, and the belts are usually very long, to give the glass time to cool and anneal. They pour it continuously out of the furnace and it hardens as the pressure from pouring it all pushes the whole thing forward. We're talking typically a quarter mile (402 meters) with some minimal friction coefficient. Imagine the pressure pouring it gives you, to push 402 meters of glass along at an even rate.

Anyway, there are two ways of making that raw soda lime glass into tempered glass. One is, as Destin described, a separate pour rig which forces air onto the surface of the molten plane, in order to cool the exterior to build up internal surface tension. The other way is to take an already cut piece of annealed and put it into a cooler oven and melt the surface and innards to do the same thing, or just melt the surface and cool it immediately. All three give the same basic result. You can also adjust the variables to change the effect, such as using less heat and cooling a bit more slowly to heat strengthen the glass, so it is in between tempered and annealed. It is strong because of the surface tension, but when it breaks it breaks in bigger chunks than does tempered, and is lighter.

The surface tension for tempered glass is so high that you can actually just barely tap an edge and cause it to burst. It takes almost no pressure. If Destin had just niked the edge instead of dropping his tempered sample, it would have easily broken. It was actually an amazing fluke that he dropped it on the edge and corner and it did not break. How I wish I had that luck, because i have slightly tapped tempered pieces on the edge while installing them and broken them.

Anyway, as he noted tempered is useful in the side windows because they're strong, but if they break they wont send huge chunks of glass at your face should you get in an accident. For the exact same reason, Federal code in the US (and almost certainly everywhere else, I just don't know any specific details about how jurisdictions outside the US work) states that glass with a high likely hood to break from normal use has to be safety glass, like in doors and near floor drains and low tot he ground. All automotive windows have to also be safteyglass. The windshield specifically, as Destin mentioned, is actually laminated annealed glass. Typically they're DS glass sandwiching a chunk of .080 plastic, heat fused so that they all adhere to one another. That makes the glass much much stronger, but also makes it so that the chunks don't fly into the vab to any great degree. Tempered glass is still stronger, but if that shattered you'd have tons of tiny shards flying towards your eyes, or it would wholly obscure your vision so a rock hitting your windshield would effectively blind you, which of course is not good when moving around at high speed in a giant chunk of metal.

Lastly, there are a ton of other kinds of glass. From high aluminum content to borosilicate like old Pyrex (incidentally, modern kitchenware "pyrxs" is actually just tempered soda-lime glass) to fancy stuff like LAS (Lithium, Aluminum, Silicate) for high temp applications like oventops and fireplaces. Some are MUCH stronger than anything you'd find in a typical automobile, but they re also so expensive that the car would cost twice as much as it already does with that one little change.

That was kind of long and sort of rambling, but since Destin made a vid about something I actually know a bit about, I thought I might as well just ramble on. If anyone bothered to read it, I hope we all learned something today.

When I was 10 years old, my paternal grandfather passed. He raised my father and his other children on a farm, and one of the pieces of farm equipment he had was a New Holland Super 77 haybaler. It had been sitting in a barn dormant for 30 years on top of 30 years of usage. My dad brought the baler back to our home, and he and I restored it over a summer, stripping it down and restoring it piece by piece, learning how everything worked in the process. That is my most cherished childhood memory, and what inspired me to go into mechanical engineering. I understand not every family has the capacity to do this though, and I like the fact that something like the Kiwi program exists to help give others the same experience I was privileged to have.
